articles.title: üìÑ ¬†How to Document Your JavaScript Package
articles.description: You‚Äôve written some useful code, you want to distribute it.. what next? Useful docs! The Deno team demonstrates the value of JSDoc and writing documentation alongside your usual source code.
articles.author: The Deno Team

articles.title: Digging Into the Promise.withResolvers() Proposal
articles.description: It‚Äôs so good to see Dr. Axel blogging again after a year away. He digs into the proposed Promise.withResolvers feature (now at stage 4) and why you might prefer to use it to create promises in a more elegant way.
articles.author: Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

articles.title: Now You Can Try the React Compiler
articles.description: A big item at this week‚Äôs React Conf was the open sourcing of React‚Äôs experimental compiler to optimize React code at build time. They‚Äôve also created a React Compiler Playground to experiment with.
articles.author: The React Team

articles.title: Make Your GitHub Profile Dynamic with Bun and TypeScript
articles.description: GitHub offers the ability to upload a profile README file that‚Äôs rendered at the top of your user page. If you want to have it dynamically update with links to your latest blog posts, statistics, or other bits of info, you can do it with a little JavaScript and GitHub Actions.
articles.author: Duy Ng

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Learn with Me: Hono
articles.description: I‚Äôm biased, since I think Takuya‚Äôs videos are amazing and am a huge fan of his note taking app, Inkdrop, but it‚Äôs neat to see someone sink their teeth into trying the Hono JS app framework.
articles.author: Takuya Matsuyama

articles.title: üïπÔ∏è¬†Athena Crisis: A Quality, JS-Powered Game
articles.description: A commercial, turn-based strategy game available on the Steam Store, but now with an open sourced engine and tooling. The game is published by Null, an indie game publisher founded by GitHub cofounder Chris Wanstrath.
articles.author: Christoph Nakazawa

articles.title: fuzzysort 3.0: Fast Fuzzy Search Library
articles.description: Check out the live example ‚Äì it certainly feels quick.
articles.author: Stephen Kamenar

articles.title: GraphQL Yoga: A Full-Featured GraphQL Server
articles.description: Create a schema, spin up a server, and you‚Äôre good to go (then you get to wire everything up). Supports GraphQL subscriptions via SSE. Designed to run across environments from Node to AWS Lambda, Deno, Bun, etc. GitHub repo.
articles.author: The Guild

articles.title: Vue Fluid DnD: An Animated Drag-and-Drop Library for Vue
articles.description: Designed for lists of items and you can view a variety of examples here, including one where the items are draggable using handles. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Carlos Jorge Rodriguez

articles.title: üóæ¬†React Google Maps 1.0: Components and Hooks for Google Maps
articles.description: Provides a way to integrate Google‚Äôs Maps API into a React app, with components to lay down markers, draw over maps, etc. GitHub repo.
articles.author: OpenJS Foundation

articles.title: Code Screenshot: A VS Code Extension to Create Code Screenshots
articles.description: It basically loads your code into this site (which you can use directly, if you'd rather not install an extension) where you can tweak settings/theme and export to either a PNG or SVG.
articles.author: Vkrsi / Visual Studio Marketplace

articles.description: zx 8.1 ‚Äì Google's tool for better Node shell scripting. Both CommonJS and ESM now supported, increased Node version support, and Deno 1.x support.
Node.js 22.2 (Current), Storybook 8.1, Astro 4.8, Bun 1.1.8
ReacType v21 ‚Äì Visual prototyping tool for React apps.

articles.title: 10 Updates from Google I/O 2024: Unlocking the Power of AI for Every Web Developer
articles.description: Google‚Äôs annual developer conference got underway yesterday, and we already have a handful of headlines for those of us working on the web ‚Äî this post outlines 10 features that Google are keen to put the spotlight on, including (to no surprise) lots of AI additions. ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Here's the developer keynote if you want to watch. We‚Äôll share more, including session videos, as they drop.
articles.author: Paul Kinlan

articles.title: Announcing the Web Platform Dashboard
articles.description: The ‚ÄòWeb Platform Dashboard‚Äô, announced at Google I/O, is a new, easy way to see a high-level overview of the entire web platform mapped out as a set of features, along with their respective browser support.
articles.author: Rachel Andrew (Chrome)

articles.title: Introducing the CSS Anchor Positioning API
articles.description: With anchor positioning built into the browser, you‚Äôll be able to build layered user interfaces without relying on third-party libraries ‚Äî it‚Äôs in Chrome as of version 125.
articles.author: Una Kravets

articles.title: The Times You Need a Custom @property Instead of a CSS¬†Variable
articles.description: Demonstrates where custom properties may be a more suitable option over variables, and showcases some of the freedom and flexibility that custom properties afford us.
articles.author: Preethi Sam

articles.title: The Modern Guide for Making CSS Shapes
articles.description: A comprehensive guide with modern techniques for creating common shapes with the smallest and most flexible CSS code possible.
articles.author: Temani Afif

articles.title: I‚Äôm Worried About the Tabbing Behavior, Rather than the Syntax and Name of 'CSS Masonry'
articles.description: Some more thoughts on the recent CSS Masonry debate, with Andy noting that we should ‚Äúworry about the basics first‚Äù.
articles.author: Andy Bell

articles.title: Hardest Problem in Computer Science: Centering Things
articles.description: ‚ÄúEven if it‚Äôs hard. Even if tools make it inconvenient. Even if you have to search for solutions. Together, I trust, we can find our way back to putting one rectangle inside another rectangle without messing it up.‚Äù
articles.author: Niki Tonsky

articles.title: Manifesto for a Humane Web
articles.description: In an age of trackers, bots, and generative AI, Michelle makes the case for a web by and for humans.
articles.author: Michelle Barker

articles.title: WordPress Studio: A Local App for Running WordPress in Dev
articles.description: There have long been unofficial ways to run WordPress on your local machine to make life easier as you set things up, design themes, etc. but now WordPress has an official, quick, lightweight, and shareable local WordPress dev environment. For Mac so far, with Windows in ‚Äòearly access.‚Äô
articles.author: WordPress

articles.title: DOM Projects: A Collection of Projects to Learn Frontend Development
articles.description: Mainly for beginners, this serves as inspiration for learning to build simple apps with JS and DOM manipulation. Choose a project to view the source and try to build the same app yourself.
articles.author: Jisan Mia Beginner

articles.title: WyW-in-JS: A Toolkit for Zero-Runtime CSS-in-JS Libraries
articles.description: Meaning ‚ÄúWhatever-you-want-in-JS‚Äù, it allows developers to build their own CSS-in-JS solution that‚Äôs decoupled from any specific implementation. As an example, Material UI‚Äôs Pigment CSS is based on this tool.
articles.author: Anton Evzhakov

articles.title: üé®¬†Color Picker: Pick Colors by Clicking on Any Image
articles.description: Upload an image then use an eyedropper tool to select pixels one at a time to generate a color palette. You can also save palettes and choose the output format (RGB, Hex, HSL). Easier than installing a local tool, perhaps.
articles.author: Rayid Ashraf

articles.title: go-masonry-gallery: A CLI Tool to Generate a Simple HTML/CSS Masonry Gallery from a Local Folder
articles.description: Note that the generated result makes use of the recently debated, still experimental Masonry feature for CSS grid layout.
articles.author: Dominick Peluso
